document: Lecture 4 – Abstract Data Types (ADT) covering linked lists, stacks, queues, trees and graphs

questions.question: A singly linked list can be traversed only in the forward direction.
Each node of a doubly linked list contains pointers to both its previous and next nodes.
In a circular singly linked list, the last node’s next pointer is NULL.
A stack follows the Last‑In First‑Out (LIFO) discipline.
Elements are removed from a queue at its tail end.
In a binary search tree, all values in the left subtree are greater than the parent node’s value.
The adjacency matrix of an undirected graph is symmetric.
free() deallocates memory that was previously obtained by malloc().
push() adds a new node to the bottom of a stack.
An edge e = (u,v) is unordered in directed graphs.
A spanning tree contains all vertices and all edges of the original graph.
Deleting a node from a singly linked list requires traversing the list from its head to locate the node.
pop() returns the value at the bottom of a stack.
isEmpty() for a queue checks that both head and tail pointers are NULL.
A leaf node in a binary tree has two children.
A graph can have multiple disconnected components.
enqueue() inserts an element at the front of a queue.
Linked lists use dynamic memory allocation so that their length can vary during execution.
In a doubly circular linked list, the head’s prev pointer points to the last node.
The pop operation on a stack must check that the stack is not empty before removing an element.
